tail: in the form of a thin sticky colorless film dental plaque

meta.context: This occurs when bacteria colonize on the tooth surface in the form of a thin, sticky, colorless film (dental plaque).

head: the bacteria in the dental plaque

meta.context: Soon after the intake of food, the bacteria in the dental plaque utilize the sugar from the food, to produce acid which dissolves the tooth surface.

head: Tooth decay
tail: in any part of a tooth

meta.context: Tooth decay can develop in any part of a tooth.
Radiographic examination also picks up signs of decay especially when it spreads (Figure 1.2) beneath the outer surface of the tooth (enamel).
Then, the affected tooth may become sensitive to temperature changes.
At some stage, the pulp will become inflamed causing pain and discomfort.
When the pulp is irreversibly damaged, the tooth becomes nonvital.
Infection can easily set in and the infection can spread through the root ends (apex).
The destruction of tooth structure will worsen without proper intervention.

head: The removal extraction of the tooth
tail: the only way out which results in tooth loss

meta.context: The removal (extraction) of the tooth may become the only way out which results in tooth loss.
If teeth are not effectively cleaned, dental plaque will accumulate on the tooth surfaces and crevices along gum margins.

head: accumulated dental plaque
tail: into a hardened deposit called calculus

meta.context: Furthermore, accumulated dental plaque may calcify into a hardened deposit called calculus.

head: The rough surfaces of the calculus

meta.context: The rough surfaces of the calculus further promote plaque accumulation, thus hastening the progress of gum disease.

head: The bacteria in the dental plaque release toxins which irritate the gum tissue
tail: in contact with leading to gum inflammation

meta.context: The bacteria in the dental plaque release toxins which irritate the gum tissue it comes in contact with, leading to gum inflammation, a condition which is still reversible.

head: The total detachment of tooth support including both gum pocket and gum recession
tail: as the loss of attachment LOA a condition which is now irreversible

meta.context: The total detachment of tooth support, including both gum pocket and gum recession, is referred to as the loss of attachment (LOA), a condition which is now irreversible.

head: Accumulation and maturation of dental plaque in gum pockets
tail: pus formation along the gum margin and abscess formation

meta.context: Accumulation and maturation of dental plaque in gum pockets may lead to more severe forms of inflammation, pus formation along the gum margin, and abscess formation.

head: Persistent gum inflammation
tail: to the destruction of bone support of the affected tooth

meta.context: Persistent gum inflammation will lead to the destruction of bone support of the affected tooth.
Without proper intervention, the supporting tissues may be completely destroyed and make the affected tooth very loose, and may even fall out easily.
